source:
Other signal processing methods are available in `StructuralVibration.jl`.

## Detrending

Detrending is the process of removing trends from a signal. This is useful when you want to analyze the fluctuations around a trend. The `detrend` function can be used to remove linear or polynomial trends from a signal.

### API

::: {.api}
**detrend**

data.text/plain:
[36m  detrend(t, y, order = 1, bp = [])[39m

  Detrend a signal [36my[39m with respect to time [36mt[39m using a polynomial of order [36morder[39m.

  [1mInputs[22m

    •  [36mt[39m: Time vector

    •  [36my[39m: Signal to be detrended

    •  [36morder[39m: Order of the polynomial (default is 1)

    •  [36mbp[39m: Breakpoints for the polynomial (default is empty)

  [1mOutput[22m

    •  [36my_detrended[39m: Detrended signal

  [1mNotes[22m

  [36morder[39m can be a vector if the trend is different over the segments defined by
  the breakpoints [36mbp[39m.

  The breakpoints [36mbp[39m are the points where the polynomial order changes. If [36mbp[39m
  is empty, a single polynomial is fitted to the entire signal.
data.text/markdown:
```
detrend(t, y, order = 1, bp = [])
```

Detrend a signal `y` with respect to time `t` using a polynomial of order `order`.

**Inputs**

  * `t`: Time vector
  * `y`: Signal to be detrended
  * `order`: Order of the polynomial (default is 1)
  * `bp`: Breakpoints for the polynomial (default is empty)

**Output**

  * `y_detrended`: Detrended signal

**Notes**

`order` can be a vector if the trend is different over the segments defined by the breakpoints `bp`.

The breakpoints `bp` are the points where the polynomial order changes. If `bp` is empty, a single polynomial is fitted to the entire signal.
data.text/html:
detrend(t, y, order = 1, bp = [])

Detrend a signal y with respect to time t using a polynomial of order order.

Inputs

  • t: Time vector

  • y: Signal to be detrended

  • order: Order of the polynomial (default is 1)

  • bp: Breakpoints for the polynomial (default is empty)

Output

  • y_detrended: Detrended signal

Notes

order can be a vector if the trend is different over the segments defined by the breakpoints bp.

The breakpoints bp are the points where the polynomial order changes. If bp is empty, a single polynomial is fitted to the entire signal.

source:
#| output: false
# Signal 1
x1 = -0.5:0.01:0.5
y1 = @. sin(π*x1) + 0.25
y1_const = detrend(x1, y1, 0)
y1_lin = detrend(x1, y1, 1)

# Signal 2
x2 = 0:0.1:20
y2 = @. 3sin(x2) + x2
y2_const = detrend(x2, y2, 0)
y2_lin = detrend(x2, y2, 1)

#| echo: false
fig = Figure()
ax1 = Axis(fig[1, 1], ylabel = "signal", title = "sin(πt) + 0.25")
ax2 = Axis(fig[2, 1], xlabel = "x", ylabel = "signal", title = "3sin(x) + x")
hlines!(ax1, 0, color = :black, linewidth = 0.5)
vlines!(ax1, 0, color = :black, linewidth = 0.5)
lines!(ax1, x1, y1, label = "Original")
lines!(ax1, x1, y1_const, label = "Constant trend")
lines!(ax1, x1, y1_lin, label = "Linear trend")
xlims!(ax1, x1[1], x1[end])

hlines!(ax2, 0, color = :black, linewidth = 0.5)
lines!(ax2, x2, y2, label = "Original")
lines!(ax2, x2, y2_const, label = "Constant trend")
lines!(ax2, x2, y2_lin, label = "Linear trend")
xlims!(ax2, x2[1], x2[end])

Legend(fig[:, 2], ax1)

display(fig);

## Gradient

The gradient of a signal is the rate of change of the signal with respect to time. Julia [![](/assets/logo/julia.svg){width=4mm}] has a lot of packages for computing the gradient of a signal. The `gradient` function in `StructuralVibration.jl` is a simple helper function built around the `gradient` function in `Interpolations.jl`.

### API

::: {.api}
**gradient**

data.text/plain:
[36m  gradient(f::Vector{Real}, t; method = :cubic)[39m
[36m  gradient(f::Matrix{Real}, t; method = :cubic, dims = 1)[39m

  Compute the gradient of a function [36mf[39m at points [36mt[39m.

  [1mInputs[22m

    •  [36mf[39m: Function values

    •  [36mt[39m: Points at which to evaluate the gradient

    •  [36mmethod[39m: Interpolation method
       • [36m:linear[39m: Linear interpolation
       • [36m:cubic[39m: Cubic spline interpolation (default)

    •  [36mdims[39m: Dimension along which to compute the gradient
       • [36m1[39m: Rows (default)
       • [36m2[39m: Columns

  [1mOutput[22m

    •  [36mdf[39m: Gradient of the vector [36mf[39m at points [36mt[39m

  [1mNote[22m

  If [36mmethod[39m is [36m:cubic[39m, [36mt[39m must be an [36mAbstractRange[39m.
data.text/markdown:
```
gradient(f::Vector{Real}, t; method = :cubic)
gradient(f::Matrix{Real}, t; method = :cubic, dims = 1)
```

Compute the gradient of a function `f` at points `t`.

**Inputs**

  * `f`: Function values
  * `t`: Points at which to evaluate the gradient
  * `method`: Interpolation method

      * `:linear`: Linear interpolation
      * `:cubic`: Cubic spline interpolation (default)
  * `dims`: Dimension along which to compute the gradient

      * `1`: Rows (default)
      * `2`: Columns

**Output**

  * `df`: Gradient of the vector `f` at points `t`

**Note**

If `method` is `:cubic`, `t` must be an `AbstractRange`.
data.text/html:
gradient(f::Vector{Real}, t; method = :cubic)
gradient(f::Matrix{Real}, t; method = :cubic, dims = 1)

Compute the gradient of a function f at points t.

Inputs

  • f: Function values

  • t: Points at which to evaluate the gradient

  • method: Interpolation method

    • :linear: Linear interpolation

    • :cubic: Cubic spline interpolation (default)

  • dims: Dimension along which to compute the gradient

    • 1: Rows (default)

    • 2: Columns

Output

  • df: Gradient of the vector f at points t

Note

If method is :cubic, t must be an AbstractRange.

source:
#| output: false
# Signal
x = LinRange(0., 3π, 100)
y = sin.(x)

# True gradient
dy = cos.(x)

# Estimated gradient
dy_approx = gradient(y, x)

#| echo: false
fig1 = Figure()
ax1 = Axis(fig1[1, 1], xlabel = "x", ylabel = "signal")
lines!(ax1, x, dy, label = "cos(x)")
lines!(ax1, x, dy_approx, linestyle = :dash, label = "gradient")
xlims!(ax1, x[1], x[end])
axislegend(ax1, position = :rt)

display(fig1);
